tn.ref: have nothing but mockery for me
tn.text: The abstract noun "mockery" can be expressed with the verb "mock."  AT: "only mock me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: whose fathers I would have refused to allow to work beside the dogs of my flock
tn.text: This shows how much he despised those fathers. They were not even good enough to be with his dogs. AT: "whose fathers I despised and would not have allowed to work beside the dogs of my flock"

tn.ref: the dogs of my flock
tn.text: The dog's relationship to the flock can be stated clearly. AT: the dogs that guarded my flock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Indeed, the strength of their fathers' hands, how could it have helped me ... perished?
tn.text: Job uses this question to mock the weakness of those men. AT: "The strength of their fathers' hands could not have helped me ... perished." or "(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: men in whom the strength of their mature age had perished
tn.text: Their strength perishing is a metaphor that represents no longer being strong but weak. The phrase "mature age" refers to them being old. AT: "men who had become old and had no strength" or "men who had become old and weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: They were thin from poverty and hunger
tn.text: The word "They" refers to the fathers of the young mockers.

tn.ref: They were thin from poverty and hunger
tn.text: The abstract noun "poverty" can be expressed with the word "poor." The abstract noun "hunger" can be expressed with the words "hungry" or "starving." AT: "They were very thin because they were poor and starving" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: they gnawed at the dry ground
tn.text: Possible meanings are that 1) "dry ground" is a metonym for the dry roots that grow in the ground. AT: "they chewed on the dry roots they found in the ground" or 2) "gnawed at the dried ground" is a metonym for eating whatever they could find in the dry ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Connecting Statement
tn.text: Job continues to talk about the fathers of the mockers.

tn.ref: saltwort ... bushes' leaves ... the roots of the broom tree
tn.text: These are plants that people would eat only if they could find nothing better.

tn.ref: the roots of the broom tree were their food
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the people ate the roots of the broom tree or 2) the people warmed themselves by burning the roots of broom trees.

tn.ref: They were driven out from among people who shouted after them as ... a thief
tn.text: The phrase "were driven out" means "were forced to leave." These phrases can be reordered and stated in active form. AT: "The people shouted after them as ... a thief and forced them to leave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: shouted after them as one would shout after a thief
tn.text: "shouted at them as though they were thieves"

tn.ref: brayed like donkeys
tn.text: AT: "cried out in their hunger;" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: They were descendants of fools, indeed, of worthless men
tn.text: AT: "They acted like people without good sense."

tn.ref: they were driven out of the land by whips
tn.text: AT: "they were driven out of the land like criminals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they do not refrain from spitting in my face.
tn.text: AT: "they even spit in my face!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: God has unstrung the string to my bow and has afflicted me
tn.text: AT: "God has taken aware my power to defend myself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Upon my right hand rise the rabble
tn.text: "Gangs of young people attack my strength" or "Mobs attack my honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: pile up against me their siege mounds
tn.text: Job knows that his enemies are preparing to attack him, just as an army prepares to attack a wall of protection around a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: like an army through a wide hole in a city wall
tn.text: Job compares his situation to a city under attack with a hole in its defensive wall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: my honor is driven away as if by the wind
tn.text: AT: "the wind has blown away my honor;" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: my prosperity passes away as a cloud
tn.text: Job's belongings have disappeared like a cloud that suddenly appears and then vanishes from the sky. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Now my life is pouring out from within me
tn.text: Job feels he is about to die. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the pains that gnaw at me take no rest
tn.text: Job speaks of his pain as if it is alive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: He has thrown me into the mud
tn.text: Job says that God has humiliated him.

tn.ref: cruel
tn.text: This word means unkind.

tn.ref: with the strength of your hand you persecute me
tn.text: The word "hand" represents God's power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: lift me up to the wind ... throw me back and forth in a storm
tn.text: These expressions represent the extreme suffering that God made Job endure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the house destined for all living things
tn.text: The "house" represents the place where dead people go. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: all living things
tn.text: That is, all things now alive, but that will die one day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: does no one reach out with his hand to beg for help when he falls? Does no one in trouble call out for help?
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "I helped people who had fallen when they begged for my help. I helped those in trouble when they called for help." or 2) "I have fallen, and so God should not think I am doing wrong when I beg for his help. I am in trouble, so of course I call out for help!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did not I weep ... trouble? Did I not grieve ... man?
tn.text: "You know that I wept ... trouble, and I grieved ... man!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I waited for light ... darkness came
tn.text: Here "light" represents God's blessing and favor and "darkness" represents trouble and suffering. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My heart is troubled and does not rest
tn.text: Job speaks of his heart as if it were a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I go about with darkened skin but not because of the sun
tn.text: Here Job refers to the darkness of his gloom and despair. AT: "I am always in gloom and darkness."

tn.ref: a brother to jackals, a companion of ostriches
tn.text: Job compares his calling out in misery to the cries of jackals and ostriches. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my bones are burned with heat
tn.text: Here "bones" refers to the whole body, which suffers from fever. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: wail
tn.text: A "wail" is a loud, long cry of sadness or pain.
